awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Summer Research Projects in Contemporary Physics
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds the Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) site in Physics at the University of Chicago.  The site will support twelve students for ten weeks of summer research at the University of Chicago each year.  The core of the program for each student is a well-defined 10- week summer research project under supervision of a University of Chicago faculty member.  The program provides students with exposure to the breadth and unity of physics, and the students will learn to communicate science by submitting a written report and making an oral presentation on their work.

The undergraduate students are introduced to many of the ideas of leading-edge research, and student projects are among: high-energy physics, cosmic-ray physics, astrophysics, general relativity, condensed-matter physics, non-linear dynamics, biophysics, and topological physics. A series of talks presented by faculty provides an overview of some of the most important research topics currently pursued in these areas of physics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Intellectual Merit : 

The Department of Physics at the University of Chicago has run a Research Experiences for Undergraduate (REU) site.

The objective was to encourage students, especially underrepresented mnorities and women)  to pursue careers in physics.  Applications were solicited nationally with emphasis on historically black colleges, minority-serving institutions, and traditional women’s colleges.  The core of the program for each student was a well-defined 10- week summer research project under supervision of a University of Chicago faculty member. 

Projects were distributed among: high-energy experiment (8), high energy theory (1), cosmology and astrophysics (23), general relativity (2),  condensed-matter physics (6) and biophysics/medical physics (1).  Biweekly lectures presented by faculty provided an overview of some of the most important research topics currently pursued in these areas of physics. 

Broader Impacts : 

We've broadened the scope of our research by introducing many of the ideas of cutting-edge research to a number of underrepresented minorities and women (10 African-American,  21 Hispanic; 1 Native Anerucan, and 20 women). 

The interns learned to communicate science by submitting a written report and making an oral presentation on their work. The program provided students with exposure to the breadth and unity of physics.  It brought the REU students into contact with one another. This created the peer interactions among students that increase the program’s excitement and vitality. 

As our tracking of previous students indicate, our REU interns typically continue in scientific careers.

Modified by: Sidney R Nagel
